title: Firefighters deserve medals, say couple after house is saved
text:
Firefighters deserve medals, say couple after house is saved ﻿NIKKI MACDONALD Last updated 12:03, February 17 2017 1News 
Drew Norriss of Norriss Photography captured Mother Nature’s fury from Cashmere on Wednesday. 
As police let Kennedys Bush residents back home for the first time, a relieved Paul and Cheryl Kiesanowski emerged with their lost cat Lily. 
The couple scrolled through photos showing just how close their home and others had come to destruction. 
While their lawn is still its bright, irrigated green, there's ash on the driveway and a lingering stench of smoke. The fire came within 200m of houses and 50m of a neighbour's gate. BRADEN FASTIER / FAIRFAX NZ 
Paul and Cheryl Kiesanowski with their cat Lily who they were forced to leave behind as they fled their home. 
READ MORE: * Christchurch family devastated their home is ash 
The cordons across the affected Port Hills area are understood to be being reviewed today, with some residents being allowed through when safe. 
This follow's last night's debacle, which saw some residents turning up to cordons expecting to be allowed through, after a Facebook message incorrectly said they were partially open. MORNING REPORT/RNZ 
Fire investigators are heading back up the Port Hills in Chch this morning, determined to find the cause of the fires which have ravaged the area this week. 
The Kiesanowskis were evacuated about 4pm on Wednesday, by which stage they could already feel the heat of the flames ripping towards them. 
Lily was nowhere to be seen so they had to evacuate without her. 
They were relieved to this morning find her back home - traumatised and hungry but otherwise OK. 
The pair say the firefighters - whose monsoon buckets are still swinging overhead as they refill from Halswell Quarry Park - deserve medals. Ad Feedback 
"It must have been a really rough night for them on Wednesday," Paul says. 
The couple is staying with their daughter in Bishopdale and, with the capsule wardrobe in the back and Lily safely recaptured, they're content to sit it out until police lift the cordon permanently.
